text: thanks for the invitation to speak here it's a pleasure to come down to stamford in which is now the berkeley summer and
still the stanford quarter um i'm going to talk today it's kind of a new talk
and reflects some more recent work in my group but also some of the older work and kind of blends that together
and it's really trying to think about this perspective about um about dealing with other agents as you're designing
the control systems and the you know the interaction of a system with other agents whether they be people or whether
they be other kind of autonomous or semi-autonomous agents how should you think about that interaction and and um
it's something that we've kind of had this uh you know evolving of opinion on but but
really the um the the kind of heart of what we've been doing in my group
since the beginning really was to focus on safety i work a lot on safety critical systems
and you'll see some of those applications here but we are really interested in
you know physical systems we do a lot with air traffic control i'll show you a couple of those projects and um you know
robotic systems where safety you know you have systems that are interacting close to people where you have
transportation systems where people are involved and safety critical is really important so so being able to have
proofs of safety and guarantees of safety is something that we've had a big focus on in my research group
um but you know traditional safety as you saw from that previous slide has quite a bit of like isolation you know
you have um an aircraft and an air traffic control system that is guided by human air traffic controllers on the
ground you know guiding through voice channels um talking to the pilot guiding the aircraft from its origin to his
destination through several sectors train systems you know they're isolated on tracks and when you see these robotic
systems for example in manufacturing they're kind of in cages or they're isolated from the people typically that
are using them and that's where you know that is starting to be um relaxed in all
of those areas so this is a this is an air traffic control project that we've had kind of a long-standing
collaboration with nasa ames which is close to stanford and it's a project where we were we spent a lot of time
observing the functions of human air traffic controllers as they were watching you know sitting on the ground
seeing through radar screens the aircraft that were coming into their sectors and then observing what they did
and trying to build decision support systems for these air traffic controllers so this is actually a um an
outcome of a one of the particular traces that we did this is sector 33 part of the oakland uh
center and um you know as you air aircraft come close together there are multiple ways
that air traffic controllers tend to tend to space them apart and they can do this typically they try to do that by
time you know speeding up or slowing down an aircraft just by a little bit to maintain a certain requisite distance
but in some cases like this one they have to do like deviations from paths and then they try to use shortcuts so if
they're going to veer off into a new jet way anyway why don't you do a shortcut so that you can get you know faster and
and then avoid collision at the same time so building an automated system that kind of mimics what the human in
the loop controllers have been doing historically is something that it's an interesting direction right it's not
necessarily what we think of as control engineers or people that work on autonomous systems uh because we might
find a better way to do it but in a system that has been guided for decades by human air traffic controllers and
there's a lot of trust built up an air traffic controller won't necessarily just take any solution that a neural net
might give you know from a decision support system so just to really be built on kind of
thinking about where they are today and gradually taking steps and that's one of the projects that we continue to work on
with nasa and here there's a lot of multi-agent interactions right it's a you know air
traffic control system you have multiple aircraft each each sector of aircraft like this this region inside the magenta
bounds typically has between 12 and 15 aircraft you know that's kind of the maximum but you know in peak times 12 to
15 aircraft at any given time so those multi-agent interactions are important
um and you know even with the air traffic control system but also in the other applications i talked about there's a growing number of new
applications and and we've been working with some of these folks so some this is an older picture of amazon prime air
zipline is a really cool uav company that's delivering medicines they started off in some of the countries in africa
and now they're um they're in the u.s they're teaming up with walmart to deliver uh medicines automatically
they're called zipline because they don't have landing gear they come in and the the aircraft basically have a hook
and they're grabbed by hooking onto a zip line and that's the capture system so there's a there's kind of a
deployment and then a recovery of the aircraft and it's it's a really cool engineering problem but also that
multi-agent interaction of having a lot of these delivering medicines and they started medicines and blood to areas
that are you know kind of remote and don't have easy access to hospitals or medical centers
we're working also with um nasa on air traffic air taxi so the new air taxi
system which is kind of an exciting area there's kind of the vehicle concept
this is one of the concepts that lilium which is a german company is building it's a tilt rotor system where the
aircraft has a vertical mode so it can you know take off and land in urban areas and
then the rotors tilt so that you can turn it into a conventional aircraft there's a whole bunch of neat control
problems there but there's also a kind of neat um a neat problem in thinking about how you integrate these new kinds
of aircraft like uavs like air taxis into the traditional air traffic system
so that's the you know the kinds of systems we've been working on with nasa include collision avoidance systems
forced landing systems for example for a uav if it has to land how do you do that safely so they're they're you know it's
often that you don't care about crashing the aircraft you don't want to hurt anybody who's on the ground for example
and then this air taxi control system um we're also there there's a bunch of really interesting kind of other vehicle
style applications that you know obviously there's the autonomous vehicle scenario and that's something that we're
also working on but these are kind of outside this so an inter a drug interdiction system is something that
that the navy and the coast guard is very interested on and and they're interested in trying to interdict small
ships that are coming from south america delivering drugs to central america that are then carried over land into the u.s
and this is a big big focus right now and so the office of naval research is asking for new research solutions to be
able to take the few resources that the coast guard and the navy can provide and kind of be able to
distribute those or figure out you know of the many many small ships they're trying to interdict what are the what
are predictive ways what are ways to infer you know what those ships are doing all sorts of interesting control
and learning problems there so i have a couple of um you know vehicle style application problems examples in my talk
but um but these are some kind of motivations of how we you know some new
maybe some new problems on the horizon that where multi-agent interactions are really featured
so i'm structured this talk really around three research projects they're kind of like vignettes
and they they kind of move um from maybe more strict assumptions about the other agents in
the system to relaxing those so i'm going to start off by talking about it's an older project in my group but older
and current we've been working on this for a long time and i'd like to introduce it as it sets a stage for how
you know how we've traditionally thought about multi-agent interactions in safety critical systems and that's through
reachability then we're going to move on to the second kind of vignette which is um
relaxing this idea that's used in reachability of you know worst case of
worst actions of the other agent worst case actions of the other agents in the system and um and think more about um
you know the less worst case actions the role of feedback as well as computationally
efficient methods when you have that scale to multiple to many agents
um there's some um there's some choice of parameters involved in these problems
and then so in the last vignette i'm going to talk about how you might use learning to aid in choosing these
parameters to infer models and behaviors of um of the other agents in the system
and i i as i said this is a new talk i was kind of thinking about the projects that are going on here that i've seen and
observed so meng shi and airdems projects and and some of the um you know
research that mac and marco have presented up at berkeley recently and michael to kind of think about you know
what's going on here and how might the kinds of things we're doing in my group interface or connect with some of those
projects okay so let's start just by this um what
is going to be kind of a review but more like an introduction review of what reachability is and and the assumptions
that we use when we compute reachable sets so uh we call it hamilton jacobi reachability because at the heart of the
computation is an optimal control or differential game problem in this case with uh like multiple players we use a
differential game formulation and there's you know we're building on um i would say uh you know a long
history of differential game theory where we derive a new problem basically
a new bellman equation that can be used to compute reachable sets and a lot of the challenge has been to first of all
represent that and then compute those reachable sets based on that um that formulation and that's called a hamilton
jacobi it's a it's a new type of hamilton jacobi equation okay so let me
kind of give a background as what that means um we're assuming that the the underlying systems the agents have
dynamics associated to them and and you can represent the joint dynamics of those systems as some kind of dynamic
system either a differential equation as is represented here with state z and input u and disturbance d or some um
difference equation for example but there's some kind of dynamics that can model the system itself
and they may be uncertain you may be able to kind of lump the uncertainty about the behavior for example in in the
disturbance which is often what we do so a reachable set is the set of states
um and there's different flavors but let's consider a problem where your control is trying to get the system
trying to get maybe one of the agents to a desired target in the face of you know other agents
which may be disrupting the plans so in that sense let's think about the control as an action which is trying to
get the system to a target set in the face of a disturbance which we may not
know what it's going to do but let's assume for the sake of safety critical control that it may be trying to do its
worse to disrupt those plans so all states for which for all possible disturbances
there's a control which can drive the system into a target set over a time horizon and so given that formulation we
use a or given that statement we use a game formulation for this a dynamic game in which the disturbance
attempts to force the system into unsafe region we don't know what it's going to do so let's assume that it could do its
worst to disrupt the control's plans while the control is trying to keep the system safe trying to get it to its
target um and these are animations that uh sylvia
herbert who's a former student in my group had created so i'm i'm i'm gratefully using her um animations for
this so if this for example is the target set in green um then for a you know a particular
dynamic um f this is a possible reachable set this is actually a reachable set of a um it's like a
dubin's car style model of those dynamics okay so how did we come about that um
the the methodology that we use is to take that set and represent it as the zero level
set of a function in one higher dimension so that's the cost function it represents the the goal the objective
the target set here um and that's uh we'll use some functional representation so you've you
know many different functions who have that set as the zero level set so you choose one here it's just a
distance to uh distance to target set function that we're using so that the zero level set of that function is the
target set itself and we'll use a representation l to represent that set okay so what then do we want to compute
we'd like to compute all states which could get to that target set um despite the worst case disturbance so we define
a value based on that goal of reaching that set and that value is a function of
the state space in this case we're using z uh so in this uh example it's a two-dimensional state space and
it's a function of time over a time horizon so basically every state z at
time t has a value associated to it which is like the future rewards or penalties
that are incurred by the system being at that state at that particular time and
in this problem that's solely related to whether or not it gets inside or stays outside the set over that time horizon
so to do that we basically define this value function as
the minimum cost of trajectories of the system starting from state z at time t
okay so this is you know why do we use minimum because we're looking at this function we've we've decided that we're
going to represent um kind of goodness as being inside that set at some point
over the time horizon and so if you want to try to be inside that site you want to try to minimize that function l so
the minimum over the time horizon from 0 to capital t of that function l
evaluated on the trajectory itself and we don't have to actually so here's
where some control can come in we don't actually have to evaluate it on all possible trajectories we only really
have to evaluate it on the best trajectory the trajectory where we use our best control input to get the system
into the target set um so that's here's the trajectory itself the trajectory is a function you
know it's an it's a solution of that differential or difference equation or whatever dynamics you use but it's a
solution of that system using the you know the a particular control and
disturbance input and if you're to be efficient we don't have to evaluate over all control and
disturbance inputs we just have to use the optimal trajectory so the best for the control despite the worst case
disturbance and that's the one where the control is trying to get the system into
the set so it's trying to minimize that function l over the trajectories whereas we don't know what
the disturbance will do in this formulation so we'll assume that the disturbance could do its worse it could try to maximize it push push you outside
that set because it's maximizing the function l evaluated over that trajectory
okay so given that definition we can define the
bellman backup equation or the update equation or the hamilton jacobi equation they're all the same thing here and this
is um well hamilton jacobi actually isaacs was the one back in the 30s well
the 40s and 50s who did a lot of work on games so these are often called hamilton jacobi isaacs equations which in this
continuous time continuous state setting is a partial differential equation which
describes the on the left hand side the change in that value function as a function of time and on the right hand
side it's a function of the state and the gradient the change in that value function as a function of state which in
our case is quite simple we don't have a running cost here we just care about
whether or not the system gets into the state over the time gets into the target set over the time horizon so we're just
looking at this um hamiltonian which is the inner product between the dynamics and the gradient of the value function
okay and um in terms of computing it we've been moving away from
using the actual pde representation and we're using now in our codes this
variational inequality it allows us in general to um have a more general
representation of targets for example we can use time-varying targets with this representation and um it has some also
some computational um uh benefits so this is basically a it's still a partial differential equation
but this kind of way that we represent it here as the minimum of the pde and
the initial data is called a variational inequality
okay so so now we solve that so this is um you know we have to basically grid up
the state space and compute that value function using that pde
at every point in the state space over time and so what we're doing here is we're
basically evaluating the we're evaluating this function v of x t
for all or v of z t for all state z and for all points in time over that time
horizon and um and then updating it over time so over that time horizon that value
function it starts at the initial green cone and then expands out into this particular set
so it basically says that every state z at time t has a value and whether or not
you're you know inside the zero level set of that value or outside the zero
level set of that value indicates whether or not that state indicates whether or not there exists a control
such that for all possible disturbances starting at that state you can get to the target set over that time horizon so
at each time we're capturing the zero level set and that captures the reachable set
okay so we just take that zero level set so here we are back to this reachable set that we showed at the beginning but that's how we compute it we we represent
sets implicitly through a value function in one higher dimension and then we're always recording i mean other values
other level sets are interesting too but generally the zero level set is what we record because that represents that sort
of binary decision of yes you're captured or no you're not captured over the time horizon
okay so that's the reachable set and you can do other things too you can
include for example um state constraints in this problem so we
um we've also have you know interesting problems where you'd like to reach a target but avoid some other sets along
the way you'd like to maintain some constraints so those states the constraints can also be represented as a
value function this is the the red set here so instead of using l for the target set let's use g for the
constraint set and then we can update the representation of the value function to
include that state constraint it's like a it's like a mask on the computation of
the reachable set you're just making sure that you can't it's not only that you want to rule out states inside the
constraints but you want to rule out states in the reachable set that could get to the constraint before they get to
the actual target set so it's like you've combined together two reachability problems one which is
getting to the target set and one which is avoiding the constraint set
and and then we update the the actual hamilton jacobi pde according to those constraints um and then do the
you know the same kind of computation which is a gridding up of the state space and solving that pde at each point
in uh space and at each point in time so that's that's the computational challenge which we'll talk about
okay so again thanks to sylvia herbert for these nice animations captures the zero level set so here you see what we
call this reach avoid set sets of states which get to the target while avoiding that constraint
okay and please feel free to interrupt and ask questions if you have questions along the way you can ask questions at
the end
okay so um like a collision avoidance problem we talked about some of these uh air traffic control or air taxi problems
um so these are these um computed reachable sets for a pairwise uh collision avoidance problem
here the dimension because we're only dealing with two aircraft and we're
looking at collision avoidance we can look at the relative dynamics so the dynamics the underlying dynamics f
become the relative dynamics between those two vehicles and then we're going to place the we'll call them pursuit
pursuer and evader using the kind of traditional isaac's game theoretic terms and then in those in that relative
coordinates space we'll place the evader at the origin and and these aircraft
have uh some kind of turning angle so we'll place them at the origin of the relative frame with a zero uh heading angle and
then i've just shown a snapshot of the pursuer in each case that's just to
indicate that the pursuer i'm looking at this is a three-dimensional set because i've have a an x-dot y-dot and z and
theta-dot where that's the those are the three states um but i'm going to take a slice of that three-dimensional set at
the case of the pursuer being at that kind of 90 degree away from the zero angle and just look at what those
sets look like and i think the reason i wanted to show this computation to you is to illustrate you know how these
computations can change when you have different information assumptions between the agents so kind of leading to
our thought about okay what are we assuming about the multiple agents in this uh in this game um
in the first case on the left is um maybe the you know in terms of the uh
evader pursuer problem it's the one which is um assuming the most about the
system which or in which the evader assumes the most about the pursuer namely that um they you know there's a
communication loss with the pursuer but the so the evader is assuming that the
pursuer is operating according to some disturbance bound doesn't know exactly
what it's going to do but it knows it has kind of a bound in what it can do and it will stay to that
and so this reachable set and you can see these indices over time represents the relative states where the pursuer
can be and collision avoidance cannot be guaranteed so if the pursuer managed to
play its worst if it were inside that reachable set at any of those time
stamps um the uh best control action of the evader
will not keep the two aircraft apart from each other and a part is that uh defined by that basically that disk
around the evader okay so this is just that hamilton jacobi reachable solution
when we're assuming that the disturbance is the action of the pursuer and we've given a bound on that
a more a less conservative approach is to assume that both aircraft we've lost
communication with both aircraft we don't know what we don't know what the pursuer is going to do within its bounds but we also don't know what the evader
is going to do within its bounds so now instead of thinking about that as a control disturbance problem it's like we
have two disturbances what's the you know if the evader did its worst case and the pursuer did its worst case
within bounds what does that reachable set look like what does that collision set look like and you can see its growth
it's actually kind of interesting it um it grows out and then because these dynamics are like a dubin's car it kind
of circles around again so you get a new part of the reachable set growing in that middle panel kind of above the the
previous reachable set and you can see there's like again time stamps associated to each of those
um and then the real worst case scenario so the the one that maybe puts the least
assumptions on what the vehicles could do is one where they actually try to collaborate to cause collision so it's
not like the middle case where you know they must by by kind of you know choosing the wrong thing accidentally
they could uh cause collision in the right panel they're collaborating and so they're really acting with each other to
try to cause collision and um and you see that you know now the set's growing even more so it's the same computation
but just different assumptions instead of using like a min max we'd be using a min min etc in these in these different
kind of information patterns what you're assuming you know and then what the implication would be in the game
formulation
okay i put this in this is from a long time ago but this is actually robly field up here i used to be a professor
here at stanford and we built maybe the first this is before you could buy a
quad rotor like anywhere we built those um these are built out of um
carbon tube carbon tubes and tube straps and we had two computers and we you know we
actually designed one of the computers and we ran another computer running the optimization algorithms on it so and
there's four students there they're each joysticking one quadrotor around and um the snapshot on the right is just
a data snapshot so around each aircraft are three different reachable sets
one reachable set for each of the three other aircraft and this is one of these interesting
problems where because of the dynamics of the vehicles and the fact that they can essentially stop and hover you can
prove that the actual unsafe set like the collision zone is the union of the
collision zones with respect to you know each uh a vehicle with respect to each of the three other vehicles
and so at every point in time we're computing these and when one vehicle gets on the boundary of its reachable
set with respect to another vehicle the other vehicle takes its best case uh
control action to keep that vehicle outside of the regional side it does that that
control input which basically in this case it's an avoidance problem so it's maximizing the control input to keep the
other aircraft away from from causing collision and getting into its reach of the set so it's like pilots the students are
joysticking the aircraft around as soon as one gets on the boundary of another the automation takes over and guides the
aircraft away from each other until a point in time where it's you know a little bit off the boundary and then
control is given back to the for the pilot so this was a a kind of both
demonstration and an experiment to show this off that you could do this and you could compute these
okay just a little bit about the toolboxes so the first level set method so we this um method for computing the
reachable set this gridding up of the state space and solving that hamilton jacobi equation and capturing the zero
level set um that's called a level set method they were pioneered like the numerical methods
were pioneered by stan osher who's a professor in math at ucla and jamie sethian who's a professor in math at
berkeley and um and so we took like sort of inspiration from that and built these
level set methods for these kinds of control problems and um and so this is the reference to this original level set
toolbox which ian mitchell who was a graduate from stanford he was my first phd student
he's now a professor and department chair of computer science at ubc in vancouver
um and then over the past several years we've had updates to this so we built in our group
a toolbox we call it helper oc it's like a wrapper around ian's level set toolbox this was um written by a couple of
different students but led by mo chen and sylvia herbert moe is now at simon fraser university in vancouver and
sylvia is now a professor at ucsd and they um they basically made it more
easy to use providing this wrapper you know easy ways to input your own dynamics
easy ways to capture the value function and you know that like to guide you in formulating the problem
and that's on our labs reachability site and then most recently we've been using
and this is a really cool toolbox it's the hj reachability toolbox which was built by ed schmerling who is a graduate
of stanford from marco pavone's group and this is a toolbox built in python and
it's built on top of the jacks computational framework and we have been doing some work with
this toolbox and have built a number of additional functions to use with this so
one of those and this is just a little bit of an aside this is a project that my student marius wigart and i have been
working on with um manon doshi and pierre larmuso who are researchers at mit
it's a carbon sequestration project where we're building light vehicles well we're working with a company that's
building light vehicles that are seaweed farms and we're trying to use minimum energy paths to get these vehicles their
you know surface vehicles in the ocean to areas of high nutrients where they can where the seaweed grows quickly and
then it can be at a certain stage deposited in the ocean floor so it sequesters carbon from the um from the
air from the environment and then deposits it where it kind of you know stays for for centuries and millennia
and maybe turns into oil at some point um but the idea here was to really use
minimum energy control by putting a very kind of low control input here that kind
of nudges the vehicles toward currents and then we use those currents to get us
to places where we want the vehicle to go so this is the gulf of mexico and if you um you know if you wanted to
get you can see these are there's a lot of databases with you know forecasts as well as we can use those for hindcast
and if you wanted to get from one point to a destination using those currents uh that
that magenta arrow up there just shows if you took it actually takes 33 days
using the currents and using the hamilton jacobi methodology but if you um if you didn't you know if there were
zero currents that arrow at the top just shows how far you would have gone over
33 days with just this uh small control input um and the you know it's kind of
neat to watch the trajectory using these eddies and these currents to as we say
hitchhike them to be able to get from the origin to the destination but the point i want to make here is that you
know using helper oc to compute that trajectory we were using backwards reachability for that trajectory because
you not only get the reachable set but you get the optimal control input that took three hours whereas in the hj
reachability which is taking advantage of parallel processing across gpus it took a much shorter time only eight minutes
okay so those are kind of state-of-the-art in um i would say this is state of the art in hamilton jacobi
reachability and it's great to be able to use that um i'd like to say one more thing about
computing these reachable sets and um this is recent work that we've done
because it is you know gridding up the state space and despite even if we have that hj reachability tool you know if we
want to do these computations in real time how do we do that um and one of the
ideas that we had been exploring with samuel bonsal who's a recent graduate of our group he's now on the faculty at usc
is to um instead of gridding up the state space and um and then just you know sort of
blindly computing the hamilton jacobi updates at each grid point over time
we train a neural net to compute that value function for us
and i think the idea is pretty cool because you um you can actually take advantage of you know the the neural net
to be able to learn you know what are the what are the best points to compute at there's probably you know a whole lot
of the grid points that are fairly you know fairly important and then others which aren't important at all and we've
done a lot of work on you know adaptive gridding and trying to choose those ourselves but the logic to do that was
always more cumbersome than actually just doing the computation so i feel like this is a this is actually a really
promising and we've seen it not just here in hamilton jacobi equations but people in computational fluid dynamics
and other kind of scientific areas where they know the equation they want to solve are using um now neural net
procedures to help them do this kind of computation okay so in this you know scenario we define a
neural net where v theta so this is our approximation of the value function here
x is the state space and typically to find the parameters like to train that neural net you'd be
you'd obtain those using supervised learning where the value function is known at some states over time but that
in itself is hard right because then you have to actually compute the value function at those states to be able to
use them to supervise the training of that neural net so the key thing about this kind of
scientific uh application of neural nets is that you can use this the equation you know the
equation you want to solve so you can use that as the source of supervision and use self-supervised
learning so the pde itself is the source of supervision and the loss that you use in training is just the pd pde violation
error okay so if you're if that right hand side of the loss function h is
non-zero it indicates that you're not satisfying your pde and so you're trying
to you're training the system to try to get your you know that function or the magnitude of that function to zero and
it means you're solving your pde then and the cool thing about that is you
know you don't have to sample the value function and that's the key to scaling so we um
we then just uh follow this loop we randomly sample states and at
points in state and time we compute the loss function we update the parameters and repeat
okay so this is um we call this deep reach so deep learning to compute reachable sets um there's a lot of
details here that i don't really have time to talk about but one of them is the form of the neural net um and you
know this is all empirical right i mean we can do these we can do these computations and then we can compare them to our grid based computations and
some functions that we know we can compute analytically but one of the keys to make this work
was to use something called a sinusoidal representation network uh siren which is a
a kind of i guess in advance that came out of stanford actually the computer vision
group here and um the idea is that because we're interested not only in you know the
value function itself but its derivative over time and its gradient we wanted to be able to have units in the neural net
which were differentiable and where where you know the control input itself is computed from the gradients so we use
um a sinus so we use sinusoidal uh um activation functions for the neural net
and then we follow this training procedure and of course there's a lot you know the
size of the neural net the number of neurons the learning procedure so we've tried out a bunch of different things
and we've we've published this la this uh this last year um but i think there's still a lot to do here in this you know
in this but in this area in general using neural nets to um aid you in scientific computation
but the cool thing is that um so this just shows you know the match for some of these low dimensional problems where
we know the solution we've actually got some sort of semi-analytic solutions to these two aircraft collision avoidance
problems they're kind of our litmus test um but that we can you know start to go higher so this is a nine dimensional
three aircraft collision avoidance problem so it's three aircraft uh it's lateral so three xy and theta three
states each you can't do relative anymore because now it's three aircraft
and uh it was a um this is a single pursuer two evader problem
um so what we've shown here are the projections of the reachable set computed via deep reach which is the
pink set for projected down onto the positions coordinates x7 and x8 or the seventh and
eight state coordinate but they're the position coordinates of the pursuing aircraft and the evader aircraft or the

the ego vehicle might follow a certain action um and if the probability of the

of probability going between zero to one it's like transferring the ownership of

so here the idea is that if p is equal to one the ego vehicle is going to avoid
the hypothesized agent and if p is equal to zero it's going to ignore the hypothesized agent so in each case you

ownership problem um basically you know it basically becomes an optimization problem in terms
of this parameter of constraint ownership and so for this interpolating factor p whether it's between zero and

constraint ownership this leads to what is a novel
optimization framework which is called a generalized feedback nash equilibrium
um basically it's you know this this constraint ownership instantiated
